comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: A real display of pride in one's workplace, rarely seen in the early years of the 21st Century!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: It is a War Memorial Gardens for tramways employees. This photo dated as 1919 on Wikipedia and Sydney Architecture sites - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rozelle_Tram_Depot www.sydneyarchitecture.com/GLE/GLE39.htm

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: The tradition continues - we have a small memorial garden at the local bus depot

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] it costs too much!

Where was this located? Is/will SRNSW do geotagging/support geotagging?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/jufemaiz] The rusty roof of the Tram Depot is still there just north of Harold Park Raceway in Glebe - no sign of the Memorial Garden except for a few palm trees - maps.google.com.au/maps?ie=UTF8&hq=&hnear=Sydney+...

comment.author: 75983496@N00
comment._content: the garden thing was a tradition that was carried on with the bus depots but its seems to have lost appeal,not sure about the Brookvale depot war memorial thought,was still popular when i worked there

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75983496@N00] Terry, the Brookvale Depot memorial is still there - that is the memorial garden I was referring to above. They still have a ceremony on ANZAC day in which they remember those who have fallen in the service of the nation.

comment.author: 57005739@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] yep. Growing up on the beaches I know that one well. Not sure there's too many old private sector companies doing anything similar - would be nice to know that there is.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is another photo showing the rear of the garden and a Memorial statue, beyond the palms - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... Also dated as 1919?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Could be 1919, I wonder where those dates come from?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/jufemaiz] We've enabled geotagging and placed this one on the map. Have fun!

AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Re 1919 date - Wikipedia article dates this photo as 1919 - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rozelle_Tram_Depot . The link to the enlargement also says 1919 - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Rozellw_tram_depot_gardens.jpg And cites this page as its source - www.sydneyarchitecture.com/GLE/GLE39.htm which says "circa 1919". But then at the bottom of the SydneyArchitecture page above, there is a link to "Rozelle Tram Depot historical images" - sydneyarchitecture.com/HP/GALL-HP-04.htm - this and other photos (possibly copies in State Records NSW) are "March 1929". Confusing! I was interested to see this on the SydneyArchitecture site - " Rozelle Tram Depot is a large tram depot in Glebe that has stood effectively empty sine the 1960s. It is currently being redeveloped as part of Mirvac Harold Park residential redevelopment and will be developed as a retail area. The vandalised trams within will be retained on site and restored. "

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is a series of 10 prints (including this photo) of the Rozelle Depot Gardens in the State Library of NSW collection, all dated March 1929. acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/search/simpleSearch.aspx?authority=pla... Moral: Don't believe everything you read in Wikipedia !

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Very confusing indeed! The photos on Wikpedia and SydneyArchitecture looked like copies of ours (undated) so it was a bit of a mystery that they were dated 1919. 

I'll put "possibly March 1929" according to the images in the State Library collection. 

Thanks for your research!

AB

comment.author: 111716589@N03
